docs.snippet: THERE will be two unfamiliar entities onstage when ''Not About Nightingales'' opens on Thursday at Circle in the Square on Broadway. First, of course, will be Tennessee Williams's fierce, lyrical prison play, having its belated New York premiere 6...
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE will be two unfamiliar entities onstage when ''Not About Nightingales'' opens on Thursday at Circle in the Square on Broadway. First, of course, will be Tennessee Williams's fierce, lyrical prison play, having its belated New York premiere 61 years after it was written. And second, playing the central role of the warden, will be Corin Redgrave, who has not been on Broadway since 1963 and who is the least known of the famous acting Redgraves. With the imposing demeanor of the politician he has often played and might have been, Mr. Redgrave, 59, is the middle brother to Lynn and Vanessa, the son of the late Sir Michael.
docs.abstract: Matt Wolf interview with Corin Redgrave, who stars in play Not About Nightingales; photos (M)i

headline.main: A Redgrave Moves Up In the Family Business

docs.snippet: THIS year's Academy Award nominations offer many reasons for deep satisfaction, but one such reason hasn't attracted much attention. Tucked at the end of the list of nominees for best foreign film, just below Roberto Benigni's ubiquitous ''Life Is...
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS year's Academy Award nominations offer many reasons for deep satisfaction, but one such reason hasn't attracted much attention. Tucked at the end of the list of nominees for best foreign film, just below Roberto Benigni's ubiquitous ''Life Is Beautiful,'' is ''Tango,'' an entry from Argentina that is the work of the hugely gifted, hugely perplexing Spanish director Carlos Saura. It would be wonderful in any case for the 67-year-old Saura to be noted again for Oscar consideration (his ''Carmen'' was nominated in 1983). But it is especially gratifying with ''Tango,'' because while ''Tango'' is certainly a dance film -- the sort of film that Mr. Saura has come to be associated with in the last 20 years -- it is not a dance film above all. Here, the director's distinctive way of depicting dance from the inside out does not overshadow his more venerable gift for commenting in a dramatic narrative on subjects like political repression, personal loss and emotional survival.
docs.abstract: Will Joyner profile of Carlos Saura, Spanish director of film Tango; photos (M)2

headline.main: A Depictor of Dance Reaches Beyond It

docs.snippet: BE COOL  By Elmore Leonard.  292 pp. New York:  Delacorte Press. $24.95.     OSCAR WILDE was probably the first to fully articulate the importance to mankind of redeeming vices. Oscar would've liked ''Be Cool.'' For one thing, there's a large gay ...
docs.lead_paragraph: BE COOL By Elmore Leonard. 292 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $24.95. OSCAR WILDE was probably the first to fully articulate the importance to mankind of redeeming vices. Oscar would've liked ''Be Cool.'' For one thing, there's a large gay Samoan bodyguard who has a nasty little habit of kissing men on the lips before throwing them over the balconies of high-rises. For another, Elmore Leonard has a nasty little habit of dead-on accurately conveying the thought processes, if lightly and humorously, of some seriously nasty people.
docs.abstract: Kinky Friedman reviews book Be Cool by Elmore Leonard (M)

docs.snippet: Songs for Brothers and Sisters    MONDAY -- The tenor Jerry Hadley will sing a benefit concert for Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City. The performance, at 8 P.M., will be followed by a reception, at Merkin Concert Hall. Tickets, $125, or $5...
docs.lead_paragraph: Songs for Brothers and Sisters MONDAY -- The tenor Jerry Hadley will sing a benefit concert for Big Brothers Big Sisters of New York City. The performance, at 8 P.M., will be followed by a reception, at Merkin Concert Hall. Tickets, $125, or $50 for the concert alone, from (212) 686-2042. Selling Teddy TUESDAY -- Greenwich House will hold its seventh Teddy Bear auction, to raise money for services to abused children. Joy Behar, the comedian, will be the host, and Leonardo DiCaprio, Madonna, Elton John, Glenn Close and Oscar de la Renta are among the celebrities who have dressed, decorated or signed bears. The event begins at 6 P.M. at Tavern on the Green and will include drinks, the silent auction and a buffet. Tickets, $125, from (212) 243-7492.

docs.snippet: THE special relationship is beginning to look awfully one-sided. For years, the assumption has been that New York and London enjoyed a uniquely symbiotic rapport, so that a major success in one city could be counted on to open -- and be appreciate...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE special relationship is beginning to look awfully one-sided. For years, the assumption has been that New York and London enjoyed a uniquely symbiotic rapport, so that a major success in one city could be counted on to open -- and be appreciated -- in the other. Ask an English theatergoer of a certain age, and one hears of the defining impact made in London by the original Broadway productions (occasionally with their New York leads) of ''Company,'' ''West Side Story'' or even ''Oklahoma!'' Both ''Annie Get Your Gun'' and ''The Sound of Music'' had longer initial runs on the West End than they did on Broadway. And while British drama of, say, the 1950's could seem stuffy and class-bound, the American work of the same period was seismically invigorating.
docs.abstract: Matt Wolf article on shift in British reaction to New York theater hits staged in London from respect to disdain, at time when American appetite for English work is on rise; photo (M)

headline.main: Words to Prompt Disdain in London: New York Hit

docs.snippet: THE British tide that periodically washes over the American theater is surging again. Already ensconced on New York stages are David Hare's ''Blue Room,'' David Leveaux's production of ''Electra'' and Harold Pinter's ''Ashes to Ashes.'' And what a...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE British tide that periodically washes over the American theater is surging again. Already ensconced on New York stages are David Hare's ''Blue Room,'' David Leveaux's production of ''Electra'' and Harold Pinter's ''Ashes to Ashes.'' And what about Diana Rigg's recent visit in ''Phedre'' and ''Britannicus'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where ''Blue Heart,'' the double bill by Caryl Churchill, winds up its run today? Then there was Matthew Bourne's ''Swan Lake,'' the ballet that played Broadway as comfortably as a musical. Speaking of Broadway, half a dozen more theaters are about to open their doors to productions that have already won attention in London: Kevin Spacey in ''The Iceman Cometh'' and Dame Judi Dench in ''Amy's View'' among them. What does it all mean? And what about traffic the other way? This special section on theater tries to answer those questions, starting off with a conversation among the three theater critics of The New York Times: Ben Brantley, Vincent Canby and Peter Marks. Their talk -- over tea and biscuits, appropriately -- was recorded by the theater editor of Arts and Leisure, Andrea Stevens, who began by asking if the crowd of arriving British productions would risk canceling one another out. Here are excerpts from the discussion.
docs.abstract: Excerpts from conversation among New York Times theater critics Ben Brantley, Vincent Canby and Peter Marks on surging tide of British theater productions in United States; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EMPRESS OF THE SPLENDID SEASON By Oscar Hijuelos. 342 pp. New York: Harper Flamingo. $25. THE Empress of the Splendid Season, the eponymous heroine of Oscar Hijuelos's new novel, is Lydia Espana, and the splendid season is, of course, a time of love -- in 1949 in New York City, to be exact.
docs.abstract: Verlyn Klinkenborg reviews book Empress of the Splendid Season by Oscar Hijuelos; drawing (M)

headline.main: The Love Life of a Cleaning Lady

docs.snippet: Robin Sara Schafer, a daughter of Diane Hofheimer Schafer and Oscar S. Schafer, both of Manhattan, was married last evening to Dr. Christopher John Dillon, the son of Audrey and John Dillon of Fort Worth. Judge Harold Baer Jr. of Federal District ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Robin Sara Schafer, a daughter of Diane Hofheimer Schafer and Oscar S. Schafer, both of Manhattan, was married last evening to Dr. Christopher John Dillon, the son of Audrey and John Dillon of Fort Worth. Judge Harold Baer Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at the Essex House in Manhattan. Mrs. Dillon, 29, is studying for a master's degree in pediatric nursing at Columbia University. She received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Hamilton College and a Bachelor of Science in Nursing degree from New York University.

docs.snippet: It was not vintage Pernell Whitaker. There wasn't much ducking. There wasn't much dodging. There wasn't any showboating. And in the end there wasn't much question in the mind of the judges that Felix (Tito) Trinidad Jr. dominated Whitaker during 1...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was not vintage Pernell Whitaker. There wasn't much ducking. There wasn't much dodging. There wasn't any showboating. And in the end there wasn't much question in the mind of the judges that Felix (Tito) Trinidad Jr. dominated Whitaker during 12 rounds of a welterweight championship bout last night at Madison Square Garden. Using a right-hand lead that battered Whitaker through much of the fight, Trinidad, 26, took control in the fifth round and cruised past the 35-year-old Whitaker, who had not fought in 16 months in large part because of a pair of drug suspensions, to take a 12-round unanimous decision and retain his International Boxing Federation welterweight championship. Trinidad (34-0) scored the only knockdown when he dropped Whitaker (40-3-1) in the second round with a powerful right that caught him on square on the chin. Whitaker said it was a flash knockdown.
docs.abstract: Felix Trinidad defeats Pernell Whitaker to retain his International Boxing Federation welterweight championship at Madison Square Garden; photo (M)
